Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation2: The nursing assistant is on a routine check-in with a patient who is feeling a bit lonely.
Story: I stared at my phone, the message from my stepmother glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the family ceremony this year. It would mean so much to your father.” My heart thudded. I knew how important these traditions were to them, how much they wanted me to be part of the family, to show I belonged. But as I tucked my phone away, Mrs. Carter, my patient, looked up at me with watery eyes. “Could you stay a little longer?” she whispered. She’d been so quiet all morning, and I knew she needed someone to talk to, someone to just be there. My supervisor expected me to give each patient the time and care they deserved, especially those who felt alone. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family needing me to step up, to prove I was one of them, and Mrs. Carter needing me to simply sit and listen. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be enough for both.
